title: Excision theorem
summary: In algebraic topology, a branch of mathematics, the excision theorem is a theorem about relative homology and one of the Eilenberg–Steenrod axioms. Given a topological space X {\displaystyle X} and subspaces A {\displaystyle A} and U {\displaystyle U} such that U {\displaystyle U} is also a subspace of A {\displaystyle A} , the theorem says that under certain circumstances, we can cut out (excise) U {\displaystyle U} from both spaces such that the relative homologies of the pairs ( X ∖ U , A ∖ U ) {\displaystyle (X\setminus U,A\setminus U)} into ( X , A ) {\displaystyle (X,A)} are isomorphic.
